questions.question:
MSA given as 12,000 ft, flying over mountains in temperatures +9°C,

QNH set as 1023 (obtained from a nearby airfield).

What will the true altitude be when 12 000 ft is reached?

In the Northern Hemisphere a man observes a low pressure system passing him to the south, from west to east.

What wind will he experience?
What is Relative Humidity dependent upon?

options.content: Moisture content and temperature of the air

questions.question: If the ELR is 0.65°C/100 m:
Height of the tropopause at 50°N:
A steep pressure gradient is characterized by:

If you fly with left drift in the Northern Hemisphere,

what is happening to your true altitude?
Sublimation:
What is the coldest time of the day?
When is diurnal variation a maximum?

QNH at Timbuktu (200 m AMSL) is 1015 hPa.

What is the QFE? (Assume 1 hPa = 8 m)
Above a stable layer in the lower troposphere in an old high pressure system is called:
Why does air cool as it rises?

options.content: The air is colder at higher latitudes
The air is colder at higher altitudes

questions.question:
When flying at FL180 in the Southern Hemisphere you experience a left crosswind.

What is happening to your true altitude if indicated altitude is constant?
Dew point is defined as:

options.content: the lowest temperature at which evaporation will occur for a given pressure
the lowest temperature to which air must be cooled in order to reduce the relative humidity
the temperature below which the change of state for a given volume of air will result in absorption of latent heat
the temperature to which moist air must be cooled to reach saturation

questions.question:
Flying from Marseilles (QNH 1012) to Palma (QNH 1015) at FL100.

You do not reset the altimeter,

why would true altitude be the same throughout the flight?

options.content: Air at Palma is warmer than air at Marseilles
Air at Marseilles is warmer than air at Palma

questions.question: From which of the following can the stability of the atmosphere be determined?
If when heading south in the Southern Hemisphere you experience starboard drift:

options.content: you are flying towards a lower temperature
you are flying away from a lower temperature
you are flying towards a low pressure
you are flying out of a high

questions.question: How does the level of the tropopause vary with latitude in the Northern Hemisphere?

options.content: It varies with longitude not latitude

questions.question: What is the tropopause?

options.content: The layer between the troposphere and stratosphere
The boundary between the troposphere and stratosphere

questions.question: Where do you find the majority of the air within the atmosphere?

Flying from an area of low pressure in the Southern Hemisphere at low altitudes,

where is the wind coming from?

options.content: Right and slightly on the nose
Left and slightly on the tail
Left and slightly on the nose
Right and slightly on the tail

questions.question:
The QNH at an airfield 200 m AMSL is 1009 hPa; air temperature is 10°C lower than standard.

What is the QFF?

options.content: Not possible to give a definite answer

questions.question: Which of these would cause your true altitude to decrease with a constant indicated altitude?
Where is the ozone layer?

An aircraft flying in the Alps on a very cold day, QNH 1013 set on the altimeter, flies level with the summit of the mountains.

Altitude from aneroid altimeter reads:
QNH is defined as:

options.content: the pressure at MSL obtained using the standard atmosphere
the pressure at MSL obtained using the actual conditions
QFE reduced to MSL using the actual conditions
QFE reduced to MSL using the standard atmosphere

questions.question: Where would you expect to find the strongest wind on the ground in temperate latitudes?

options.content: In an area of low pressure
In an area of high pressure
In the warm air between two fronts

questions.question: Landing at an airfield with QNH set the pressure altimeter reads:

options.content: zero feet on landing only if ISA conditions prevail
the elevation of the airfield if ISA conditions prevail

questions.question: You are flying in an atmosphere which is warmer than ISA, what might you expect?

options.content: True altitude to be the same as indicated altitude
True altitude to be lower than indicated altitude
True altitude to be the decreasing
True altitude to be higher than indicated altitude

questions.question: The environmental lapse rate in the real atmosphere:

options.content: has a fixed value of 2°C / 1000 ft
has a fixed value of 0.65°C / 100 m
has a fixed value of 1°C /100 m

questions.question:
Airfield is 69 metres below sea level, QFF is 1030 hPa, temperature is ISA -10°C.

What is the QNH?

The QNH is 1030 hpa and at the transition level you set the SPS.

What happens to your indicated altitude?
What is the movement of air relating to a trough?
What is the movement of air relating to a ridge?
What is the min. temperature according to ISA?

The temperature at the surface is 15°C, the temperature at 1000 m is 13°C.

The atmosphere is:

You are flying from Madrid (QNH 1012) to Paris (QNH 1015) at FL80.

If your true altitude and indicated altitude remain the same then:

options.content: the air at Madrid is warmer than Paris
the air at Paris is warmer than Madrid
your indicated altitude must be changing

questions.question:
If you are flying on a QNH 1009 on very cold day and you circle the top of a peak in the Alps,

your altimeter will read:

options.content: the same as the elevation of the peak
lower than the elevation of the peak
higher than the elevation of the peak

questions.question: What is subsidence?
Relative humidity increases in:

options.content: warmer air compared to colder air
warm air at a constant vapour pressure
cold air at a constant vapour pressure
colder air compared to warmer air

questions.question: Which of the following gives conditionally unstable conditions?
A mass of unsaturated air is forced to rise till just under the condensation level. If it then settles back to its original position:
What height is the tropopause and at what temperature?
Which of the following will give the greatest difference between temperature and dew point?
Solar radiation heats the atmosphere by:

options.content: heating the surface, this then heats the air in the atmosphere
heating the water vapour in the atmosphere directly
heating the water vapour directly unless there are clouds present

questions.question: What affects how much water vapour the air can hold?
Aerodrome at MSL, QNH is 1022. QFF is:
What is the technical term for an increase in temperature with altitude?
On a surface weather chart, isobars are lines of:
Which of the following constituents in the atmosphere has the greatest effect on the weather?
Which of the following is true? QNH is:

options.content: can never be above or below 1013 hPa

questions.question:
If an aerodrome is 1500 ft AMSL on QNH 1038,

what will be the actual height AGL to get to FL75? (27 ft = 1 hPa).

Altimeter set to 1023 at aerodrome. On climb to altitude the SPS is set at transition altitude.

What will indication on altimeter do on resetting to QNH?
Secondary depressions move:

options.content: around the primary in a cyclonic fashion
round the primary in an anticyclonic fashion

questions.question: What temperature and pressure conditions would be safest to ensure that your flight level clears all the obstacles by the greatest margin?

options.content: Temp less than or equal to ISA and a QNH less than 1013
Temp more than or equal to ISA and a QNH greater than 1013

questions.question:
In a shallow pressure distribution (widely spaced isobars or low pressure gradients) you observe the aneroid altimeter of a parked aircraft for 10 minutes (no thunderstorms observed).

The reading of the instrument will:

options.content: not be influenced by the air pressure
show no appreciable change due to such a minor pressure fluctuation

questions.question:
You are flying from Marseilles (QNH 1012 hPa) to Palma de Mallorca (QNH 1012 hPa) at FL100.

You notice that the effective height above MSL (radio altitude) increases constantly.

Hence:

options.content: one of the QNH values must be wrong
you have the altimeters checked, as their indications are obviously wrong
the air mass above Palma is warmer than that above Marseilles
you have to adjust for a crosswind from the right

questions.question:
You are flying from Marseilles (QNH 1026 hPa) to Palma de Mallorca (QNH 1026 hPa) at FL100.

You notice that the effective height above MSL (radio altitude) decreases constantly.

Hence:

options.content: one of the QNH values must be wrong
the air mass above Marseilles is warmer than that above Palma
you have the altimeters checked, as their indications are obviously wrong
you have to adjust for a crosswind from the right

questions.question:
Flying at FL135 above the sea, the radio altimeter indicates a true altitude of 13 500 ft.

The local QNH is 1019 hPa.

Hence the crossed air mass is, on average:

options.content: there is insufficient information to determine the average temperature deviation

questions.question:
You are flying in the Alps at the same level as the summits on a hot day.

What does the altimeter read?
To dissipate cloud requires:
A layer of air can be:

options.content: conditional; unstable when unsaturated and stable when saturated
conditional; unstable when saturated and stable when unsaturated
neutrally stable when saturated and unstable when unsaturated

questions.question: Relative humidity:

options.content: is not affected by air expanding and contracting
does not change when water is added
changes when water is added, even if the temperature is the same

questions.question: What happens to the temperature of a saturated air mass when forced to descend?

options.content: It heats up more than dry because of expansion
It heats up less than dry because of evaporation
It heats up more than dry because of sublimation
It heats up less than dry because of latent heat released during condensation

questions.question:
An airfield has an elevation of 540 ft with a QNH of 993 hPa. An aircraft descends and lands at the airfield with 1013 hPa set.

What will its altimeter read on landing?
When is pressure altitude equal to true altitude?

options.content: When the indicated altitude is equal to the pressure altitude

questions.question: What happens to the temperature of a saturated air mass when descending?

options.content: Heats up more than dry because of expansion
Heats up less than dry because of evaporation
Heats up more than dry because of compression
Heats up less than dry because of latent heat released during condensation

questions.question: The DALR is:
Which of the following defines RH?

options.content: Amount of water held/ amount of water air could hold × 100

questions.question: A winter day in N Europe with a thick layer of SC and surface temperature zero degrees C. You can expect:

options.content: decreasing visibility due to snow below the cloud base and light icing in cloud
high probability of icing in clouds, severe icing in the upper levels due to large droplets
turbulence due to a strong inversion, but no icing due to clouds being formed from ice crystals
reduced visibility and light icing in cloud

questions.question:
TAF 130600Z 130716 VRB02 CAVOK =

Volmet 0920 28020G40KT BKN050CB OVC090 TEMPO TS =

options.content: TAF is correct Volmet is wrong
Volmet speaker surely must have mixed up airports because there is no way that TAF & Volmet can differ by that much
Conditions just turned out to be much more volatile than originally forecast

questions.question: What will be the position of the polar front depression in 24 hours time, assuming the usual path of movement of the polar front depression?
The Harmattan is:

options.content: a NE wind over NW Africa between Nov - April reducing visibility with dust
a SE wind over NW Africa between Nov - April reducing visibility with dust

questions.question: Which of the following factors have the greatest effect on aircraft icing?

options.content: Aircraft speed and curvature of the airfoil
Aircraft speed and size of cloud droplets

questions.question: In which of the following regions does polar maritime air originate?
What is the validity of a significant weather chart:
On the route London to Bombay, which feature would you most likely encounter between 30E and 50E?

options.content: Polar front jet in excess of 90 kt
Subtropical jet in excess of 90 kt

questions.question: Where is the ITCZ in July?

options.content: 10 - 20N over East Africa and the Arabian sea
